awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Phononic Properties of Colloidal Nanocrystal Superlattices
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Abstract
Electricity, light, sound, and heat are common phenomenon encountered in everyday life. Materials that enable advanced control over the transmission of electricity and light are known as electronic and photonic materials, respectively. These materials have made possible numerous modern technologies such as laptops, cellular phones, fiber optics, lasers, and microscopes. In contrast, technological control over sound and heat has lagged far behind that of light and electricity. This project focuses on the creation of phononic materials that could enable advanced control over the transmission of sound and heat. These phononic materials will consist of organized nanoparticle-molecule assemblies that possess vibrational characteristics that do not arise in naturally occurring materials. These assemblies will then be used to create filters, mirrors, and one-way valves that manipulate the transmission of sound and heat. This project is also integrated with a variety of educational activities. It will engage K-12 students and help train future STEM educators through the Science is Fun program at the LeRoy Eyring Center for Solid State Science. In addition, a laboratory module on phononic crystals will be developed for undergraduate students. Research results will be incorporated into a graduate student course on nanoscale heat transfer. 

Technical Abstract
Phononic crystals are artificially structured materials with periodic variations in acoustic impedance (i.e., alternating hard and soft materials). This periodicity results in a phononic band gap that enables the creation of many phononic devices such as phonon filters, waveguides, diodes, and mirrors. The objectives of this project are to: (1) Demonstrate the potential of nanocrystal superlattices for phononic applications, (2) Achieve phononic band gaps in the > 100 GHz regime for 3-dimensional phononic crystals, (3) Control transmission and reflection of heat transporting phonons in nanocrystal superlattices, and (4) Create high frequency phononic devices such as phonon filters, mirrors, and diodes. The phononic band gap center and phononic band gap width will be tuned via nanocrystal size and composition as well as ligand composition. DNA will also be used to direct nanocrystal assembly and enable diverse structural possibilities. To ensure mechanical, chemical, and thermal stability of the superlattices, the DNA linkers will be converted into an inorganic matrix via sol-gel chemistries. Phonon transmission and reflection will be experimentally studied using phonon spectroscopy, which uses monochromatic phonon generators and detectors to directly measure frequency-resolved phonon transport. These experiments will be complemented with computational modeling that calculates the phononic band diagram and simulates phonon transport using plane wave expansion methods and finite-difference time-domain methods, respectively. The nanocrystal superlattices will also be integrated with substrates by growing them from templates fabricated via electron beam lithography; thereby opening the door for future chip-integrated applications.

por.por_cntn:
Colloidal nanocrystals are a particular kind of nanomaterial that consists of a crystalline inorganic core particle with ligand molecules bound to the surface. These materials can also self-assembly into periodic arrays known as “nanocrystal superlattices,” that in principle could enable new pathways for the vibrational wave transport of sound and heat (phonons). Intertwined with phononic properties are also the underlying sound velocity, mechanical properties, and thermal properties of these materials. This project set out to investigate the phononic properties of colloidal nanocrystal films and colloidal nanocrystal superlattices. 

The intellectual merit outcomes of this project include the use of machine learning and finite element analysis to demonstrate that colloidal nanocrystal superlattices are in fact 3-dimensional phononic crystals with incredibly high frequency band gaps (center frequencies > 100 GHz). In addition, we experimentally showed that ordering in nanocrystal superlattices leads to approximately 3x improvements in both thermal transport and mechanical properties relative to colloidal nanocrystal films (which lack the long-range order of superlattices). The ligands on the surface of the nanocrystal were identified as both a thermal and mechanical weak-point, and so we also demonstrated that ligand-crosslinking could overcome this weak-point and lead to an approximately 4x thermal transport improvement. In addition, we showed that a ligand-exchange procedure with inorganic ligands could lead to approximately 60x improvements in mechanical properties. The broader impacts of these findings are important to new technologies and devices that are based upon colloidal nanocrystal materials. The unique electrical/optical properties of colloidal nanocrystals make them of interest for electrical, optoelectrical, photovoltaic, and thermoelectric devices (in addition, colloidal nanocrystals are already being used commercially in television displays). The thermal and mechanical properties of nanocrystals also play in important role because these devices must meet thermal management and mechanical robustness demands (alongside electrical and optical demands) to achieve true success in industrial settings. Consequently, this project’s demonstrated routes to improving thermal and mechanical properties of colloidal nanocrystals deepen our fundamental understanding of these materials as well as increase the opportunities to successfully utilize them in commercial applications. 

The research results of this project have been disseminated to the scientific community via several means: (i) four publications in peer-reviewed journals,  (ii) five invited conference presentations, (iii) four contributed conference presentations, (iv) two PhD dissertations, and (v) two MS theses. An additional journal manuscript submission is also anticipated after submission of this report. This project also created training and educational opportunities for many people. Five PhD students and two MS students worked on the research portion of this project. In addition, this project also delivered science presentations on thermal energy in K-12 classrooms and at community events throughout the Phoenix metropolitan area via Arizona State University’s “Science is Fun” program. Results from this research are also being regularly incorporated into university curriculum as well.
